observations: Input grids contain a single non-background color.
Output grids contain the same non-background color as the input.
The non-background color appears in multiple locations in the output, often replacing background colors surrounding the original input non-background color.
In the output, the original non-background color is often present in the same location as in the input.
The output grid contains a color with the value of 2 and 3 as well as the original non-background color
Color 2 usually appears on the same horizontal or vertical axis as the location of color 1 in the input.
Color 3 surrounds areas containing color 1 or color 2 in the output grid.
Color 1 is always horizontally and vertically aligned with original color 1.
hypotheses: The output grid has the same dimensions as the input. The location of the non-background color in the input is used as a central point. The original non-background color is duplicated to form a cross. New colors 2 and 3 fill in spaces in the output.

The non-background color in the input is used as a seed point. The surrounding area is filled with the original non-background color and two more colors are used based on the position of the original color.
selected_rule: The output grid has the same dimensions as the input. The location of the non-background color in the input is used as a central point. The original non-background color is duplicated to form a cross. New colors 2 and 3 fill in spaces in the output.
step_plan: Identify the location of the non-background color in the input grid.
Create an output grid with the same dimensions as the input grid, filled with the background color.
Place the non-background color at the same location as the input grid.
Fill the locations horizontally and vertically with color 1.
Place color 2 on the horizontal and vertical axis from color 1
Fill regions near color 1 and color 2 with color 3.
